HEALTH EQUITY & DISPARITIES
IN A 21st CENTURY PANDEMIC
2021 Summer Symposium: Addressing Differential Impacts of COVID-19 in New York State

The COVID-19 pandemic exacted a starkly unequal toll on New Yorkers of color – both in terms of the virus itself and the accompanying social and economic impacts of the pandemic. These are not separate issues. They stem from the structural racism embedded in American society. Minority health disparities have always existed in the United States. But COVID-19 has exposed and exacerbated these disparities in ways we cannot ignore; doing so would mean accepting inequity with life and death consequences. The COVID-19 pandemic also exposed gaps in existing knowledge about the causes of these inequities and, more important, how to end them. This Symposium is a product of a new health equity research and collaboration ecosystem at UAlbany launched in April of 2020 with extreme urgency at the height of the most serious public health emergency New York has faced in a century. The ecosystem is helping to close these gaps through new knowledge, insights, and recommendations to combat future public health threats we have yet to even imagine.

The 2021 Summer Symposium entitled, “Differential Impacts of COVID-19 in New York State,” is designed to support the efforts of university researchers and government policymakers who have pledged to do everything in their power not to allow the lessons learned from COVID-19’s unequal path across New York to go unheeded.
This is a virtual symposium, via Zoom webinar. Accommodations will be provided. Detailed agenda is forthcoming.
Should you have any questions about the 2021 Summer Symposium, please contact Ms. Sarah Murphy
